title: Herbert Watson (footballer)
text:
Herbert Leonard Watson (20 November 1908 – 13 October 1939) was an English professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Right%20half-plane">right half</a> who played in the <a href="the%20Football%20League">Football League</a> for <a href="Middlesbrough%20F.C.">Middlesbrough</a>, <a href="Brentford%20F.C.">Brentford</a> and <a href="Bristol%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bristol Rovers</a>. He is best remembered for his time with Brentford, for whom he made over 100 appearances.
Playing career.
Middlesbrough.
Watson began his career at <a href="Non-League%20football">non-league</a> club Pelton Fell and joined <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> club <a href="Middlesbrough%20F.C.">Middlesbrough</a> in May 1926. He made his debut in a 4–1 <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> victory over <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday%20F.C.">Sheffield Wednesday</a> at <a href="Ayresome%20Park">Ayresome Park</a> on 7 December 1929. Watson made semi-regular appearances for the club through to the end of the <a href="1929%E2%80%9330%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1929–30</a> season and scored his first goal for the club in a 5–1 win over <a href="Birmingham%20City%20F.C.">Birmingham City</a> on 8 February 1930. He made 13 appearances during the campaign. Watson failed to make an appearance during the <a href="1930%E2%80%9331%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1930–31</a> season and made his first appearance in nearly two years when he played in a 1–1 draw with <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a> on 26 December 1931. He made one further appearance during the <a href="1931%E2%80%9332%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1931–32</a> season and departed Middlesbrough at the end of the campaign, having made just 15 appearances during his six years with the club.
Brentford.
Watson signed for <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20South">Third Division South</a> club Brentford in May 1932, joining former Middlesbrough teammates <a href="Jack%20Holliday">Jack Holliday</a> and <a href="Billy%20Scott%20%28footballer%20born%201907%29">Billy Scott</a> at <a href="Griffin%20Park">Griffin Park</a>. He led the club to promotion to the Second Division as <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a> in the <a href="1932%E2%80%9333%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1932–33</a> season and to the First Division for the first time in the club's history in 1935. After the signing of <a href="Dai%20Richards">Dai Richards</a>, Watson lost his place in the team and managed just 13 appearances in the First Division during the <a href="1935%E2%80%9336%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1935–36</a> season (in which Brentford secured their highest-ever league placing of fifth). He departed the club at the end of the campaign, having made 109 appearances and scored one goal during his four years with the club.
Bristol Rovers.
Watson and Brentford teammates <a href="James%20Raven%20%28footballer%29">James Raven</a> and <a href="Les%20Sullivan">Les Sullivan</a> dropped back down to the Third Division South to join <a href="Bristol%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bristol Rovers</a> during the 1936 off-season. He made 19 appearances during the <a href="1936%E2%80%9337%20Brentford%20F.C.%20season">1936–37</a> season before retiring from football.
Honours.
Brentford
